reason.tex:
%text Below are two facts about lines in a 2D plane that are the backbone of this chapter
$\quad\bullet$ Only one line can pass through two points $A$ and $B$ $\quad\bullet$ Whilst infinite lines can pass through a point, only one of those lines can have a given slope $(m)$
The above two facts give rise to the following equation forms for a line.
\textbf{Given two points} Given two point $A=(x_A, y_a)$ and $B = (x_B, y_B)$
\[ \qquad \dfrac{y-y_A}{x-x_A} = \underbrace{\dfrac{y_A-y_B}{x_A - x_B}}_{\text{Slope } m}\]
If $A = (x_A, 0)$ and $B = (0,y_B)$ be where the line cuts the $x$ and $y$ axis respectively, then
\[ \qquad \dfrac{x}{x_A} + \dfrac{y}{y_B} = 1 \]
\textbf{One point + Slope} If you know only $A$ and $m$ -- but not $B$, then
\[ \qquad \dfrac{y-y_A}{x - x_A} = m \]
